transcripts.text: The Court of Appeal at the High Court yesterday ruled that the government's policy on expanding the airport, that third runway, which is not just sort of adding a third, it's effectively a whole new Gatwick airport, all intents and purposes at Heathrow.  The court ruled yesterday that the government's policy on expanding the airport was unlawful because ministers had failed to take proper account of how it affected Britain's climate commitments.  This is particularly the Climate Change Act and also the net zero by 2050 carbon emissions pledge.  But a refusal to properly consider the UN Paris Agreement, which limits rises in global temperatures, well, is aimed at limiting rises in global temperatures, was legally fatal, the judges said.  This has a massive knock-on effect for every other airport project in the country, road projects.  rail projects and any energy projects as well.  Government said it would accept the ruling.  It's still not known yet whether or not Heathrow will decide to actually appeal that decision, although very likely that they will.  Well, we'll get the thoughts of Dave Chawna and Russell Quirk on that in just a couple of moments.  First up, though, let's talk to Caroline Russell, who's London Assembly member and transport spokeswoman for the Green Party.  Good morning to you, Caroline.
Hi.  Good morning.

Now, you and many other green activists have been campaigning against the Heathrow.  I mean, basically, you know, since before some of my listeners were born, it's been going on for that long.  A big victory for you yesterday.  But the knock-on effects of this are huge, aren't they?

Well, I think it is a massive victory.  And the expansion at Heathrow, I mean, Londoners have been campaigning against that on so many grounds, on noise grounds, on air pollution grounds.  People being overflown by planes waking them up at night, very early in the morning, So there are lots of reasons why Londoners are not keen on expanding Heathrow Airport.
Can I clarify?  Some Londoners are very keen on it, particularly the local boroughs are closest to Heathrow.  They're actually very much in favour of it because of the extra jobs.

Well, can I just say, I mean, in the London Assembly, every single political party is against Heathrow expansion.  So?  Because of the impact on Londoners.  That includes the people who were UKIP, it includes the Conservatives.  Labour, the Lib Dem and the two Greens.  So it's not that odd a position to take.  And in terms of... climate change, we're currently seeing the impacts of changing weather, of more extreme weather all across the country.  Your intro just around the news, there was a whole thing about more flooding happening and the worries about this new storm that's coming and whether it's going to impact those flood-hit communities.

The impacts of climate change are really having an effect on people's lives, and we do need to take it seriously.  Caroline, my darling, the current storms and the current flooding we've got have got nothing to do with climate change.  They have to do with the jet stream and the Arctic vortex.  Do you not understand these things?  Your Green Party campaign, surely this is stuff you should know as your bread and butter.
The point is...
No, no, you do accept that, don't you?  No, you've just made... No, Caroline, you've just...
...are going to be more frequent if you have climate change.

The IPCC latest report, last report on that, said there was a... I think it was low... What was the phrase?  It was not low probability, but low expectation that that was actually the case.  There is no direct correlation and there's no proven causation between those things.  We've actually not seen an increase in extreme weather around the world, whether it be droughts or flooding.  We just see it in different parts of the world.  It is different.  We're more aware of it because we have 24-7 TV news now.  But let's just go back.  Let's go back and talk.
You must have heard the communities around Worcester and Shrewsbury explaining how they never have had floods like this.
They have had floods like this before.
After record-breaking flood.
Caroline, they have had floods like this before.  They have.
They haven't had them with the frequency and the intensity.  And that's the point about climate breakdown.  This extreme weather is becoming more common.

OK, OK, it's not.  But I'm sorry to keep throwing facts at you.  I know this is going to be throwing you.  But let's come back to the implications of this on major infrastructure projects.  Now, we've got HS2 going ahead, something which I definitely disapprove of, because I think it's just not good value for money economically for this country.  But even a project like HS2, which is rail travel, which Greens are supposed to be in favour of, as opposed to road or air travel, even that could be hit under this Court of Appeal ruling yesterday, which would suggest that anything... that contributes to more carbon emissions could be ruled unlawful under the current terms on which the government is allowed, within its own terms now, to behave.  We've got China.  By 2025, China is planning to build 137 whole new airports.  Now, I'm not saying we want to be like China.  It's a totalitarian state.  They don't care about things like planning permission or pollution and things like that.  But... There must be some middle ground between, you know, insisting, for instance, on quieter aeroplanes, on fewer emissions, on limiting the times, which could be done around Heathrow Third Runway, that would allow us the economic expansion that that would entail and the economic boom and the jobs, but wouldn't have such a major impact on pollution.

I think the thing is, what we have to do is rethink our economy completely.  Business as usual is over.  And we have to get on and invest in the renewable energy, the things that are going to make people's lives better, make their homes more affordable for heat by having better insulation.  There is a massive task to be done to actually improve everyone's homes, to make sure that we've got low-carbon transport options.  That's going to create jobs.  That's going to create a whole new economy.  And that's the stuff that we should be doing.

Did you think that there's an issue, though, in terms of this sort of, I mean, not many people will call it sort of virtue signalling by the British government, which actually has no real net effect.  Even if we did, for instance, get to net zero emissions by 2050, even if that was feasible, we'd probably only do it by cutting our own manufacturing, cutting our own air transport and road transport.  but at the same time basically transferring that to overseas.  So, for instance, we won't build an energy plant here.  We'll just import it from another country where they may be less green.  We're going to be importing more goods from China, where we know they are, and India, where we know they're far less green than we are.  And actually, ultimately, the net effect on the world's carbon emissions is going to be higher rather than lower, while we sort of bask in the glory of the virtue signaling of how well we've done at cutting our carbon emissions.

The point is, if we're going to cut our carbon, we're going to do it by making our world better.  What does that mean?  And our world will be better with more renewable energy and with these good new jobs that are going to come out of making everyone's lives better.
Carolyn, could you address the point I actually made to you?

Well... Not if their homes have been properly insulated.

do you not accept that?  Don't you think it's important that a country like, you know, a place like the UK, that we are doing absolutely everything we can to protect future generations?

I mean, I think that's a strange position to take, but at least it would be an honest position.  Do you accept that my point is valid or do you think my point is invalid?
Well, personally, rather than... I mean, you're saying, oh, dear, this judgment means we can't build...

...more dirty power stations.  Well, actually, we need to be investing in the renewable energy that will actually deliver energy and not make our...
